OperatorName: P P Tangg LLC c/o Davis Property
SafetyInspectionBy: Orange County Health Care Agency - Env. Health

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This Executive Summary contains 6535 Caballero Blvd's administrative and operational programs to prevent ammonia-related accidents and reduce potential risks for the property located in Buena Park, California.  The regulated substance of concern and focus of this document is anhydrous ammonia.  



The following topics are addressed in this Executive Summary:



?    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

?    Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

?    Hazard Assessment Summary

?    Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

?    Five Year Accident History

?    Emergency Response Program

?    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

?    External Events/Seismic Summary



The following Data Elements sections are attached as part of the EPA RMP submittal:



    Section 1:    Registration Information

    Section 2:    Toxics - Worst Case Release 

    Section 3:    Toxics - Alternative Release 

    Section 4:    Flammables - Worst Case Release (NOT APPLICABLE)

    Section 5:    Flammables - Alternative Release (NOT APPLICABLE)

    Section 6:    Five Year Accident History (NOT APPLICABLE)

    Section 7:    Prevention Program 3 Component 

    Section 8:    Prevention Program 2 Component (NOT APPLICABLE)

Section 9:    Emergency Response Component



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



The management is not only committed to offering superior service, but also to maintaining a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities.  The safety and environmental policies are administered by the Property Manager and the tenants who conduct periodic inspections of the facility to ensure compliance. The Property Manager oversees the entire safety and environmental programs, including the CalARP Program.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



The ammonia refrigeration system is located on a 55-acre parcel currently owned by PP Tango CA, LLC, formerly owned by Westcore Properties, PRI

Buena Park Industrial CA, LLC, Overton Moore Properties (OMP), and by Albertson's (who merged with Lucky).  The facility is located at 6535 Caballero Boulevard in Buena Park, California, which is approximately 1.3 miles west of Interstate 5, and 0.55 miles north of Highway 91. PP Tango CA, LLC, and its agents is responsible for implementation of the PSM/RMP/CalARP Program inside the Engine Room (Machinery Room). The two property tenants (Simply Fresh, LLC and True Fresh) adhere to the PSM/RMP/CalARP Program requirements and are responsible for implementing the PSM/RMP/CalARP requirements in their respective areas outside of the Engine Room. The area immediately surrounding the facility is urban with a mixture of commercial, industrial, and residential areas. The facility location with respect to the surrounding area is shown in Figure 1.



The facility consists of a warehouse storage building of approximately 140,000 square feet.  The building is cooled via an ammonia refrigeration system that maintains a maximum of 12,688 pounds of ammonia.  Figure 2 shows the layout of the 6535 Caballero Blvd facility.



The ammonia refrigeration system is a closed system that cycles the refrigerant from liquid to gas and back again.  The system, consisting of vessels, piping, valves, and process equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for the cooling and storage of fresh food products.



Changes in pressure are directly related to changes in temperature (i.e. lowering the ammonia pressure lowers its temperature).  Low pressure (cold) liquid ammonia provides refrigeration by removing ambient heat.  Removal of ambient heat causes the liquid ammonia (contained within the system) to vaporize.  Heat is later removed from the ammonia and discharged to the atmosphere as it is condensed back into a liquid.  Typical

operating conditions range from 6 psig on the low pressure side of the system to 170 psig on the high side. 



The refrigeration cycle begins with the transfer of liquid ammonia from the Evaporative Condensers (3) to the High Pressure Receiver.  The High Pressure Receiver feeds high pressure liquid ammonia to the High-Temperature Liquid Pump Recirculator (LPR-H1), the Intercooler, and 8 high temperature evaporators (Dock and Coolers 5 and 6).  High pressure liquid ammonia is also sent to the High Temperature Compressors HC2 and HC3 and the Booster Compressors BC1 and BC2 for liquid injection oil cooling.  It also receives transfer liquid from the Liquid Transfer Unit (LTU-1).



The LPR-H1 supplies pumped liquid to 17 evaporators located in Cooler Rooms 1, 2, 3, 4, and 7. The rooms serviced by these evaporators range from 35F to 45F.  The evaporators use fans to blow air across the coils, which transfer heat from the room to the ammonia inside the coils.  As this occurs, the ammonia partially vaporizes (boils) as it absorbs heat from the product and room.  The resulting 'wet suction' (liquid/vapor mix) is returned to the LPR-H1.  In the vessel, the vapor (high stage suction) is drawn from the top by the High Stage Compressors HC2 and HC3.  The LPR-H1 also supplies high temperature recirculated liquid to the Low-Temperature Liquid Pump Recirculator (LPR-L1).  



The LPR-L1 supplies pumped liquid to six (6) evaporators located in the Freezer (-15F).  The ammonia, flowing through coils located within the evaporator units, partially boils as it removes heat from the product and room.  The resultant liquid/vapor mixture from each evaporator in the Freezer is routed back to the same vessel.  The liquid drops to the bottom of the vessel and is transferred to the Liquid Transfer Unit LTU-1 and the vapor (low stage suction) is drawn from the top by the Booster Compressors BC1 and BC2.  



Excess liquid ammonia from the Liquid Transfer Unit LTU-1 is

then discharged to the High Pressure Receiver to be reused in the refrigeration of the warehouse.



The Intercooler receives high pressure liquid from the High Pressure Receiver to maintain a liquid level in the vessel to cool the booster discharge from the Booster Compressors BC1 and BC2.  The booster discharge is cooled as it circulates through the high pressure liquid make-up bath in the Intercooler.  The high stage suction is then pulled by the High Stage Compressors HC2 and HC3. 



The compressors (two-stage) maintain a constant pressure in the respective liquid pump recirculator vessel based on the suction setpoint.  There are two booster compressors (BC1 and BC2) that collect low pressure vapor (6.2 psig) from the LPR-L1.  Discharge from the booster compressors (50 - 65 psig) flows to the intercooler where it is dispersed below the liquid level.  The Intercooler serves to cool the super-heated vapor from the Booster Compressors BC1 & BC2 prior to the second stage of compression at the High Stage Compressors HC2 and HC3.  These compressors pull medium temperature vapor (50 - 65 psig) from the Intercooler and LPR-H1. The hot gas (high stage compressor discharge - 150 psig) is delivered to three condensers (1 not in service), where latent heat in the ammonia vapor is discharged to the atmosphere, causing it to condense.  Hot gas is also used for defrosting the evaporator coils on an automatic timed cycle, to transfer liquid from the Liquid Transfer Unit LTU-1 to the High Pressure Receiver, and to cool the glycol in the Glycol Heat Exchanger.  



The Glycol Heat Exchanger is designed to be used in a separate, closed loop system for underfloor heating.  The Glycol Heat Exchanger receives hot gas discharge from High Stage Compressors HC2 and HC3.  As the high temperature ammonia vapor passes through the heat exchanger unit, it is partially condensed as the glycol absorbs heat from the ammonia.  The resulting 'wet suction' (liquid/vapor mix) flows to the LPR-L1.

At the Condensers, air (fans) and water (pump) are used to condense the compressor discharge into high pressure liquid, which then drains to the High Pressure Receiver to begin the refrigeration cycle again. The system is also equipped with an Auto Purger that removes non-condensables, i.e. air, from the system.

 

All process equipment and piping are designed according to ASME standards.  All ASME vessels are equipped with pressure relief valves that vent to the Ammonia Diffusion Tank at 250 psig except for the Intercooler and Low Pressure Liquid Pump Recirculator which vent at 150 psig.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



In order to operate the ammonia refrigeration system, the facility complies with the California Office of Emergency Services (Cal-OES) California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.



Administrative Measures:  The facility operates in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines and standards including the following:



?    ANSI/IIAR 5-2013 and ANSI/IIAR 7-2013, "Suggested Safety and Operating Procedures When Making Ammonia Refrigeration Tie ins "

?    ANSI/IIAR 6-2019, IIAR Minimum Safety Criteria for a Safe Ammonia Refrigeration SystemIIAR, "A Guide to Good Practices for the Operation of an Ammonia Refrigeration System"



The ammonia refrigeration system at 6535 Caballero Blvd has many safety features.  Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.  For example, the facility operates in accordance with the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.  It is important to note that the refrigeration system has been designed with several safety features to prevent the accidental release of ammonia. For example, the compressors are equipped with safety mechanisms that will cause the units to shut down if operating conditions exceed designated safety limits.  Al

so, level indicators, alarms, and switches are installed in key points within the system to monitor the supply of liquid ammonia and to ensure that a vessel is not overfilled.  Pressure relief valves on all pressure vessels protect the equipment from over pressurization.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



An investigation into the facility conducted at the time of the Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation (November 10, 2020), revealed that there have been no releases in the past five years (November 2015 to November 2020) of ammonia that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds. 



However, on 1/28/2019 there was a small ammonia release of <100 lbs of ammonia at the True Fresh evaporator resulting from a forklift impact.  There were no reported injuries resulting from the release. See the incident investigation forms at the facility for more details on the ammonia incident. 

 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The facility has an Emergency Action Plan (plan) in effect.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:  



?    save lives;

?    minimize and avoid injuries;

?    protect the environment; and

?    minimize property damage.





The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year. This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the CalARP regulations.  



The two property tenants have personnel circulate throughout the plant, taking note of unusual conditions in any portion of the system.  In the event that an ammonia leak is discovered, the person nearest to the leak will alert any personnel in the immediate area who are unaware of the danger and the Emergency Coordinator.  The Emergency Coordinator will determine what procedures and personnel are necessary to remedy the problem.

Emergency agencies will also be notified as necessary as outlined in the Emergency Action Plan.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation performed on November 10, 2020 included a discussion of any changes to the ammonia system in the past five years, Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) study, and Checklists which generated mitigation measures (recommendations) to improve safety at the facility.



The recommendations generated from the Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation study includes updating the piping diagrams to reflect current on-site system, key maintenance-related tests/inspections, and enhanced emergency response policies and procedures.  The property tenants' safety committee is planning to complete several items, including the recommendations, over the next year, as a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees.  These changes include the following items:



1.    Continue to train all employees in the facility Safety Plan/Programs.



2.    Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.



3.     Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.



4.    Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.

 

EXTERNAL EVENTS/SEISMIC SUMMARY



External events were considered during the HAZOP Revalidation study to evaluate their potential to impact the ammonia systems.  For example, external events such as vehicular accidents, sabotage, war, and seismic activity were addressed as any type of catastrophic failure (i.e. a line break).  An External Events Analysis Matrix was also used to guide the Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation Team through potential scenarios.  The likelihood of each scenario was established and its impact on the safety of the ammonia refrigeration systems was evaluated.  The completed External Events Analysis Matrix is also included in Appendix C of the Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation Report.



Seismic Ass

essment



In accordance with the CalARP Program seismic guidelines, a walkdown was performed by Lee Benuska, Structural Engineer, on October 22, 2001 with a revalidation on October 23, 2006, and further revalidations by Grace M. Riley, Argos Engineers, Inc. on October 25, 2011, and on July 18, 2017.  The results of the walkdowns were recorded on worksheets.  The complete report is included in the Revalidation binder under the tab labeled "2017 Seismic Assessment Update".



All recommended actions from the initial Seismic Assessment and the 2006 Seismic Assessment Revalidation have been addressed and are considered closed.  The 2011 Seismic Assessment Revalidation generated twelve recommendations which all but two recommendations have remained. The 2017 Seismic Assessment Revalidation has generated no additional recommendations.
